Award.AwardTitle: Origins of early individual differences in self-regulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Conduct problems in childhood increase risk for school failure, adolescent substance use, and criminality in adulthood. Little is known, however, about the early antecedents of childhood conduct problems in prenatal through late toddler stages. To address this research gap, this project examines family influences on the development of self-regulation, specifically executive functions and behavioral self-control, in early childhood. The key broader impacts of this research include new knowledge about mechanisms that increase risk for conduct problems and insights into ways to prevent these problems from developing into poor lifetime outcomes.

In this study, the researchers will follow a sample of 400 expectant mothers and their partners over three years and collect a variety of data on physiology, behavior in structured interactions, and executive function and emotion regulation. A major innovation of the project is its focus on the role of stress and stress hormones in the development of both parents and children. The researchers are interested in ways in which high levels of stress hormones in the expectant mother influence the child prenatally through effects on nervous system development and also on mother-child, mother-father, and father-child interaction in infancy through toddlerhood. A second innovation of this project is a focus on fathers and the ways in which fathers may decrease or increase risk associated with maternal factors. A third area of innovation concerns the international nature of the sample, which will include 200 expectant mother-father pairs in the United Kingdom and 100 each in the United States and the Netherlands. This aspect of the proejct will allow the researchers to conduct cross-country analyses and assess the generalizability of the findings and perhaps suggest how cultural factors impact development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this study was to extend our understanding of the significance of thewellbeing of parents in the transition to parenthood children’s cognitive control. We examined linksbetween multiple risk factors and assessed whether maternal and paternal wellbeing eachindependently predict cognitive control in toddlerhood. To do this, we successfully recruited nearly 500cohabitating couples in heterosexual partnerships expecting their first child across three countries: TheUnited States (New York City area), the United Kingdom (East England), and the Netherlands. Data werecollected from both parents in families’ homes when mothers were in their last month of pregnancy,and again from both parents and the developing child when children were 4 months, 14 months, and 24months of age. Across the three countries, 97% (468) of eligible families enrolled in the studyparticipated in at least two of four data collection time points.With regard to the major goal of examining links between parental wellbeing and EF/behavioralcontrol in toddlerhood, preliminary results suggest both mothers and fathers’ prenatal anxiety anddepression during pregnancy was related to children’s internalizing problems (i.e., fearful, withdrawn,and anxious behavior) at 24 months. Further analysis revealed that this intergenerational transmissionof depressed and anxious behaviors occurred via the couple relationship quality. This suggests childrenmight be able to sense and respond to relationship problems that manifest as an extension of poorparental wellbeing. In contrast, mothers’ prenatal wellbeing was also associated with children’sexternalizing problems (i.e., aggressive and defiant behavior) at 24 months over and above the role ofparent relationship quality. Importantly, and perhaps as a reflection of the stability in wellbeing overtime, changes in wellbeing in the transition to parenthood were not associated with either childinternalizing or externalizing problems over and above starting levels.Other significant results and outcomes have also resulted from this project. For one, this is oneof the first studies to develop measures to reliably measure executive function—cognitive andbehavioral control skills that are related to the achievement of goals—in children at ages 1 and 2. Inaddition, preliminary findings have found negative relations between time spent watching electronicscreen-based media and sleep in early infancy, and between early screen-based media exposure andchildren’s executive function. Several other analyses are currently being pursued


Last Modified: 11/15/2018
Modified by: Clancy B Blair
